meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>helicopter</radical> the <radical>leader</radical> is in has the most <kanji>value</kanji>! He would only choose to fly the very best one, after all. That's why it's worth way more than the others. Actually, any helicopter he flies goes up in value. That's the amazing effect of a good leader.
meaning_hint: Can you understand the value of this helicopter? The leader flew it to war and back! So of course it's worth a lot!
reading_mnemonic: To further increase the helicopter's <kanji>value</kanji>, the leader bought himself a <reading>ca</reading>r (か) and then tied them together. Now it has the value of a helicopter AND a car! Wow!
reading_hint: Imagine driving a valuable car with the leader's helicopter on top. Yeah!

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>leader</radical> can <radical>fix</radical> the <kanji>value</kanji> of certain goods and services. Leaders basically get to decide how much everything is worth in value, like rice or lamps or how much you get paid for the work you do.
meaning_hint: Imagine having a wonderful leader who values your work and time and so the value you get from working is high. Now imagine a terrible leader, who thinks you should be working at all times and doesn't find any value in what you do. Life will be a lot harder...
reading_mnemonic: This leader has fixed the <kanji>value</kanji> of <reading>chee</reading>se (ち), making it ￥1 permanently. One yen! That's, like, less than a penny! Unfortunately, the leader won't fix any of the other really expensive things... so now everyone only eats cheese.
reading_hint: Imagine if you could fix the value of cheese to something. How much would you make it cost? If you were a dairy farmer you'd probably be pretty pissed about the leader making it this low.

meaning_mnemonic: That <radical>scarecrow</radical> with the <radical>knife</radical> is the <kanji>vice</kanji> president. Yeah, I know how he looks, and I'm pretty sure he does some murdering on the <kanji>side</kanji>, but you didn't hear that from me.
meaning_hint: I don't know how we managed to get a knife-wielding scarecrow as a vice president, there's a side of politics I don't get, I guess. I mean, just look at him up there. If something happens to our president we're stuck with that thing.
reading_mnemonic: It's the <kanji>vice</kanji> president's turn to speak at the podium and he just clears his throat and yells, "<reading>F**k</reading> (ふく) you!" to the crowd, holding up his knife. They cheer.
reading_hint: What's going on? Normally if a vice president yells f**k you there would be... I dunno... consequences? What's happening?!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>womb</radical> is a <radical>circle</radical> of <radical>power</radical> where a <kanji>force</kanji> of nature is formed. The womb has the power to create life. Life is a force of nature, and the circle of life starts in the womb.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself in the womb, the circle of power. You’re being born into the world. Feel the force of your mother all around you.
reading_mnemonic: Now pretend you're the mother. You'll need all the <kanji>force</kanji> you can muster to bring that baby into the world, so you grab hold of your special <reading>sa</reading>ber (せい) and slice it about in the air to give you the extra force you need.
reading_hint: All that force works wonders, and when the baby's born you slice through the umbilical cord with your saber.

meaning_mnemonic: You <radical>kiss</radical> <kanji>each</kanji> of your best pals to show them how much you love and care for them. You kiss each friend right on the mouth.
meaning_hint: Imagine kissing each of your best friends on the mouth. Does this make you uncomfortable? Excited? Both? Feel that feeling.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, <kanji>each</kanji> of your best pals are of the <reading>cock</reading> (かく) variety. By that, I mean they are both roosters. Imagine kissing both of these cocks on their beaks.
reading_hint: Kissing the cock beak is kind of a strange experience. Feel the feathers in your hands as you steady the cock to kiss it. Cock-a-doodle-doo!

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> is like an <radical>escalator</radical> you use to <kanji>suck</kanji> and <kanji>inhale</kanji> things into your body.
meaning_hint: If you're ever having trouble remembering how to suck or inhale, just picture an actual escalator that leads into your mouth. That'll definitely help.
reading_mnemonic: Use this mouth ability to <kanji>suck</kanji> <reading>cu</reading>cumbers (きゅう) into your mouth. Cucumbers are shaped like cylinders so you can suck them into your mouth like this. Just as nature intended.
reading_hint: You can inhale a cucumber too, I suppose, but don't tell anyone I told you to.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> who knows how to use a <radical>bathtub</radical> will have to <kanji>manage</kanji> all the baths for the other Vikings. Vikings aren't so great with bathing... if you can get one Viking to figure it out he has to manage the rest of them.
meaning_hint: Picture a Viking trying to manage his Viking friends so they'll use the bathtub properly. He has to manage which people go in when, how hot or cold the water is, and provide all the soap. It's a very important job.
reading_mnemonic: The poor Viking trying to <kanji>manage</kanji> all the others keeps having to confiscate <reading>a</reading>corns (えい). "You can't take baths in acorns and wood, it has to be water!" he shouts.
reading_hint: Some of the Vikings managed to fill their bathtubs with acorns and are trying to rub themselves clean with them instead of water...

meaning_mnemonic: Can you look at the <radical>dirt</radical> and know which <radical>direction</radical> you need to go? Then you might be a <kanji>monk</kanji>. Monks have amazing skills like that. And I'm sure you've seen monks wandering around in lots of media. They don't need maps or smartphones. They just look at the dirt and let the earth guide them to where they need to be.
meaning_hint: Picture a monk walking through a large field in the middle of nowhere. He knows where to go, he's not afraid. The dirt will lead him in the right direction.
reading_mnemonic: You want to know the <kanji>monk</kanji>'s trick so you hide behind him for a while as he walks. Finally the monk stops, looks around, takes out a <reading>bow</reading>ling (ぼう) ball and starts bowling in the dirt. The bowling ball rolls off, the monk follows it, and then heads off in that direction.
reading_hint: Imagine a monk bowling in the middle of the road. Imagine your shock at how well he handles the ball. Also, imagine how heavy it must be for a monk to carry a bowling ball everywhere!

meaning_mnemonic: Under the <radical>dirt</radical> in the <radical>ground</radical> is a <radical>drunkard</radical> with something in his <radical>mouth</radical> from a <kanji>region</kanji> in North America. He died from whatever it is that’s in his mouth. That’s how this drunkard ended up under the ground in the first place. His whole face region is disfigured from whatever he ate. I wonder what region of North America the strange object came from?
meaning_hint: Try and imagine yourself unearthing this dead drunkard and trying to figure out what’s in his mouth. Smell the decay of flesh as you poke around in his mouth, trying to figure out what this thing is. Think of an object and what region of North America it comes from.
reading_mnemonic: In an attempt to identify what <kanji>region</kanji> of North America the thing in the drunkard’s mouth came from, you touch it and try to remove it with your bare hands. Upon touching whatever it is, you find it to be all <reading>icky</reading> (いき) and gooey. Like, super icky. So icky that you barf in the region immediately adjacent to you.
reading_hint: Imagine touching this super icky substance from the drunkard’s mouth. It’s really icky. Feel yourself throwing up as you feel the icky goo in the region between your fingers.

meaning_mnemonic: “Bring in the <radical>next</radical> <radical>woman</radical> so that I may examine her <kanji>figure</kanji>!” We’re holding auditions for a commercial and we need to find a woman with a nice figure. The last woman was no good, so bring in the next one.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself as a figure judge on this panel. You need to find a woman with the perfect figure to cast in your commercial. You'd cast yourself, but you just aren't confident (Ridiculous! You're special, and beautiful, and no matter who you are [yes you reading this right now] you should be proud of who you are!).
reading_mnemonic: The next woman comes in and you examine her <kanji>figure</kanji>. The figure you've been searching for! It just happens to belong to a <reading>shee</reading>p (し) woman. But she's soft, fluffy, and round. The perfect figure!
reading_hint: We should all try harder to have a figure like this stunning sheep woman!

meaning_mnemonic: It may just be a <radical>roof</radical> over a <radical>bathtub</radical>, but this here is actually a <kanji>Shinto shrine</kanji>.
meaning_hint: It is indeed just a roof over a bathtub, but I guess spirits inhabit everything according to Shintoism, so there's no reason this bathtub can't be a Shinto shrine too.
reading_mnemonic: What god does this <kanji>Shinto shrine</kanji> hold? You see that "It's a-<reading>me-ya</reading> (みや)! (Mario!)"
reading_hint: It makes sense, the person who says "It's-a-me! (Mario)" is someone who works on bathtubs (and plumbing).

meaning_mnemonic: From the <radical>roof</radical>, an <radical>icicle</radical> falls and hits <radical>wolverine</radical> in the <radical>forehead</radical>, and he has to go over to the <radical>stool</radical> to <kanji>lie down</kanji>. And eventually he goes to <kanji>sleep</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Picture this entire scene. The icicle falls in slow motion from the roof. It hits wolverine right in the middle of his forehead. He goes down. He has to lie down. He has to sleep.
reading_mnemonic: While wolverine <kanji>sleep</kanji>s, he makes a horrible <reading>neigh</reading>ing (ね) sound. It's like there's a giant horse in his mouth screaming to get out! NEIGH NEIGH!
reading_hint: Wolverine might have a concussion that's making him neigh in his sleep. I guess it's good that he's lying down, but I'm pretty sure you're not supposed to sleep... Maybe you should wake him up so the neighing will stop—I mean, so he'll be okay!

meaning_mnemonic: If someone gets under the <radical>canopy</radical> over your <radical>heart</radical> you should <kanji>respond</kanji> to them.
meaning_hint: You usually ignore everyone, but this one person... they really got under there and touched your heart. You finally feel like they're the right person to respond to.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>respond</kanji> and it turns out it was to the <reading>王</reading> (おう).
reading_hint: The 王 touched your heart, you responded, and now you're together. It's like a fairy tale!

meaning_mnemonic: You have a great <radical>ability</radical> because your <radical>heart</radical> gives you the <kanji>appearance</kanji> of a superhuman. Your heart is really strong and powerful, fuelling your body to the best of its ability. All this together gives you the appearance of someone in top condition.
meaning_hint: See yourself in this ideal appearance. Everyone loves to look at you because you look so awesome. Your heart has given you many great abilities. Feel strong and powerful in this body of yours.
reading_mnemonic: While you may have the <kanji>appearance</kanji> of someone who is super strong, powerful, and awesome, you do have one shortcoming. You don’t know how to <reading>tie</reading> (たい) a tie. Actually, you don’t even know how to tie your shoes, let alone your tie. How embarrassing.
reading_hint: Since you don’t know how to tie a tie or tie your shoes, you wear slip ons and clip ons. Hear the noise of Velcro being undone as you kick off your shoes and unclip your tie after a hard day’s work at the office.

meaning_mnemonic: Pointing your <radical>fingers</radical> to the <radical>sun</radical> is the <radical>correct</radical> way to <kanji>present</kanji> yourself or offer to <kanji>submit</kanji> your ideas. You're really just raising your hand. And when you want to present yourself, your ideas, or offer anything, the correct way is to raise your fingers to the sun. You definitely learned this in school.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself in class. You want to present next! You want to submit your ideas for class approval. So raise those fingers to the sun the correct way and wait for your teacher to call on you.
reading_mnemonic: You want to <kanji>present</kanji> your show and tell of <reading>ta</reading>ter tots (てい) to the class. You raise your hand, the teacher calls on you, and you <kanji>submit</kanji> the tater tots for her and the class's approval. "Oh my!" the teacher exclaims, "I hope you brought enough tater tots to present to the whole class!" You raise your hand once more to the sky, and in it you submit a whole tray of tater tots!
reading_hint: The next time you have to submit work in class just raise your hand and give everyone tater tots. Instant "A" material.

meaning_mnemonic:
You use your <radical>fingers</radical> in the game of <radical>football</radical> to <kanji>aid</kanji> and <kanji>assist</kanji> the other players. And when you smash your fingers in football, you need to get some aid yourself.

If you're from the UK, just imagine someone kicking or stomping on your fingers instead.
meaning_hint: Picture yourself playing football. You catch the ball with your fingers and then assist your team by running and smashing your body into the enemy team. But in the process you smash your fingers... so you need to go to the aid tent.
reading_mnemonic: When you need <kanji>aid</kanji> for your football wrecked fingers you can't help but feel like it's the <reading>en</reading>d (えん) for you. Your fingers hurt so much, you don't even want the nice nurses to aid you.
reading_hint: You can't assist your team anymore because you got hurt. This isn't fair! It's the end. The end of your life and your career. Boo hoo hoo!

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>ground</radical> of the <radical>rice paddy</radical> is a <radical>treasure</radical>. As you pull it out of the mucky ground, you can feel your life force being<kanji>renew</kanji>ed.
meaning_hint: Seems like the treasure has some magical ability to renew the cells in your body. Really try to imagine this feeling as you pull the treasure out of the rice paddy’s ground. Perhaps it feels just as refreshing as getting a full night’s sleep.
reading_mnemonic: Just as you were getting accustomed to this life <kanji>renew</kanji>ing treasure, <reading>こう</reading>いち comes out of nowhere, stealing your treasure and running off with it.
reading_hint: All you could hear was a sly “yoink!”, and suddenly your life renewing treasure was gone. God knows what things こういち will get up to with this life renewing treasure in his possession (but it sure won’t be anything good).

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>cheap</radical> <radical>tree</radical> has a <kanji>plan</kanji>. A plan to stay cheap.
meaning_hint: Picture a tree coming up with some elaborate plans to make sure they can spend as little money as possible.
reading_mnemonic: The cheap tree's <kanji>plan</kanji> involves only buying <reading>an</reading>chovies (あん) and surviving on them. Good exposure to the sun and fresh water is too expensive. The tree plans to save money by eating anchovies.
reading_hint: You're not sure about this anchovy plan. Are you cheap enough to choose a life of eating only anchovies?

meaning_mnemonic: See all those <radical>icicle</radical>s to the <radical>dog</radical>'s left? Good thing they all fell on his left, or he would've been in a terrible <kanji>condition</kanji>.
meaning_hint: Picture a bunch of big, sharp icicles all falling down directly next to this dog. Now imagine the condition he would've been in, had they all fallen directly on top of him. Poor little thing.
reading_mnemonic: What saved the dog's <kanji>condition</kanji> was none other than <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the local farmhand. He constantly keeps an eye on the dog's condition, including any dangerously sharp icicles that could descend on him.
reading_hint: Good guy Joe, always worrying about his dog's condition. Everyone needs a farmhand like Joe.

meaning_mnemonic: You can use a <radical>jackhammer</radical> to <kanji>indicate</kanji> and <kanji>show</kanji> someone where the prize is buried. You buried the prize to keep it safe, but the jackhammer is great at unearthing it. Jackhammers do a great job and show where the treasure lies. They indicate quite clearly where one needs to go.
meaning_hint: Imagine using this jackhammer to show someone where the prize is buried. Feel the vibrations through your hands and the rest of your body.
reading_mnemonic: Actually, you're unearthing <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). He’s the treasure. For your soul. He’s here to show you that Jesus is still a hip and cool guy and he wants to <kanji>indicate</kanji> to you that having faith in Jesus and God and stuff is super rad. Jesus is all like, “Who has two thumbs and wants to <kanji>show</kanji> you the way of the Lord? This guy.”
reading_hint: Picture Jesus getting all over the top and super preachy about his religious beliefs. He’s doing everything he can to indicate to the crowd that he’s the best, and show them how cool he is. Listen to Jesus preach to the crowd, desperate for their attention.

meaning_mnemonic: With a <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>tree</radical> resting atop your <radical>head</radical>, you devise a <kanji>plan</kanji>. The plan is actually for getting the bamboo tree off of your head. You’re trapped under it.
meaning_hint: Imagine being trapped under this bamboo tree that is resting on your head. You’re stuck. Feel the weight of the bamboo tree pressing on your head as you try and devise a plan to get out from under it.
reading_mnemonic: But why is this bamboo tree so heavy? You look to each end of the bamboo and realize that there is a <reading>sack</reading> (さく) tied on each end. Each sack seems to be filled with heavy rocks. Looks like someone made a <kanji>plan</kanji> to trap you here. Now you have to devise a plan to escape!
reading_hint: Bamboo is usually kind of light, but this bamboo has a sack of rocks tied to each end making it heavy. Imagine yourself trying to remove this bamboo tree by pushing it up and away from you. It’s like doing a bench-press, bamboo style.

meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>bamboo</radical> <radical>saw</radical> to cut down <radical>tree</radical>s to <kanji>construct</kanji> and <kanji>build</kanji> a building. The bamboo saw was crafted by a master bamboosmith, and cuts through trees with ease so you can quickly construct this new building.
meaning_hint: Imagine yourself working the bamboo saw. It's made of bamboo, but its sharp edge glistens with a mysterious aura as you slice through tree after tree. Feel how unnaturally easy it is to cut down piles of logs to build with.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>construct</kanji> and <kanji>build</kanji> this building, you hear a strange cheeping noise. Suddenly a <reading>chick</reading> (ちく) pops out of one of the logs you are building with. Then another, and another. You're surrounded by chicks! Is this because you used the magical(?) bamboo saw??
reading_hint: Imagine trying to construct the rest of this building covered in baby chicks. They're very cute, but this is dangerous! You have to build very carefully, so you don't accidentally hurt any of them.

meaning_mnemonic: You take all of your <radical>thread</radical> and <radical>allocate</radical> them into one place to <kanji>unite</kanji> them. With all your thread united and wrapped together, you're ready to <kanji>rule</kanji> and <kanji>govern</kanji> the world!
meaning_hint: Allocate all of your thread like you would your cash: by uniting it! Not at a bank, but in a big, intertwined lump. Now nobody can stop you and your big lump of thread!
reading_mnemonic: You're busy trying to <kanji>unite</kanji> all of your thread, twisting and tying and wrapping, and suddenly you look at the ball in your hands and see <reading>とう</reading>きょう. You've united this thread into the shape of とうきょう. There are even little pins for all the famous neighborhoods and tourist spots. This is strange, because you don't remember putting them there.
reading_hint: Try to do this yourself at home. Unite all of your thread and poof! There's とうきょう!

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>net</radical> needs to be <radical>fix</radical>ed if you want to <kanji>put</kanji> food on the table.
meaning_hint: You can't put something in your net if it's broken. Fix it!
reading_mnemonic: Once it's fixed, you <kanji>put</kanji> a bunch of <reading>chee</reading>se (ち) in the net. You want to catch something that eats cheese, so that you can then put that animal on your dinner table.
reading_hint: Imagine putting a bunch of cheese in your now-fixed net. It kinda stinks!

meaning_mnemonic: If you try to <radical>say</radical> things with a <radical>knife</radical>, the police will put you in a <radical>net</radical> as your <kanji>penalty</kanji> for breaking the knife laws. You can't just go up to other people and say things with a knife out.
meaning_hint: Imagine getting so mad that you use a knife instead of words to say what you're trying to say. A net falls over you and pulls you down. The knife goes flying. This is your penalty for acting like a crazy person.
reading_mnemonic: Your <kanji>penalty</kanji> for breaking the law isn't over. Now that you're stuck in a net, you can't fight back when they hit you with <reading>bats</reading> (ばつ).
reading_hint: If you don't want to be punished with bats, maybe next time don't use a knife instead of your words.

meaning_mnemonic: The light of the <radical>moon</radical> is shining on a <radical>guard</radical> who’s been on duty all night. In fact, the moon light is making him so warm, he’s trying to <kanji>undress</kanji> and <kanji>escape</kanji>! Somebody stop him!
meaning_hint: Picture the guard being so warm from the moonlight that he’s trying to simultaneously undress and escape. You can’t just let him leave his post!
reading_mnemonic: You’re unable to stop the guard from <kanji>undress</kanji>ing and making his <kanji>escape</kanji>, so you decide to start throwing some <reading>darts</reading> (だつ) at him. Perhaps that’ll make him stop.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself desperately throwing darts at the undressing, escaping guard, trying to make him stop. Or perhaps trying to pin his clothes to his body using the darts. Anything to stop this madness!

meaning_mnemonic: The only <radical>flowers</radical> that the <radical>moon</radical> <radical>gladiator</radical>s will <radical>water</radical> are <kanji>wisteria</kanji>.
meaning_hint: The moon gladiators have a thing for wisterias.
reading_mnemonic: Since they're on the moon, where did they get the <kanji>wisteria</kanji> from? Actually, from one of the points on earth that is nearest to the moon, Mt. <reading>Fuji</reading> (ふじ).
reading_hint: Imagine them reaching down from the moon and plucking some wisteria up from Mt. Fuji then taking them back up to the moon. Now they water them.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>clothes</radical> radical and the <kanji>clothes</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Surprising!
reading_mnemonic: An <reading>ea</reading>gle (い) sees a pile of your <kanji>clothes</kanji> and lays an <reading>e</reading>gg (え) in them. The eagle’s egg needs a soft warm place to incubate, and your pile of clothes is the perfect place.
reading_hint: Look at the eagle and her egg sitting atop your clothes. Every time you get close the eagle starts to screech at you fiercely. Screee! Screee!

meaning_mnemonic: A mix of <radical>spirit</radical> and <radical>reason</radical> helped you invent the <kanji>sleeve</kanji>. Your spirit told you your arms were uncomfortable, stuck to your sides under that shirt. Reason told you that maybe, just maybe, if you made holes for your arms something good would come out of it. And that's how sleeves were born!
meaning_hint: Your spirit and your arms are free! Imagine how unreasonable life was without sleeves. How on earth did you survive without them?!
reading_mnemonic: And without these <kanji>sleeve</kanji>s, your arms would be <reading>so de</reading>ad (そで). They'd be all exposed and defenseless!
reading_hint: Imagine all the ways your arms would be so dead if you didn't have sleeves. Sunburn, bug bites, miscellaneous cuts and scrapes... Just so, so dead. Good thing you've got sleeves.

meaning_mnemonic: There's an <radical>arrow</radical> in a <radical>turkey</radical> that you can <radical>see</radical> in your <kanji>view</kanji>. The turkey seems to be viewing you too, from afar.
meaning_hint: View the turkey as the turkey views you. View the arrow stuck in it too.
reading_mnemonic: As you <kanji>view</kanji> the turkey, Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん) suddenly comes into your view too. He towers over the injured turkey, leans down, and... pulls the arrow out!?
reading_hint: As you view this strange scene, Genghis Khan turns and views you viewing him. He points two fingers to his eyes and then to you, and marches off into the woods. You also view the turkey running off in the other direction.

meaning_mnemonic: You should <radical>say</radical> "<radical>peace</radical>" before you <kanji>evaluate</kanji> a situation. That way everyone will know where you’re coming from. If you’re honest and say "peace" before you evaluate a situation out loud, everyone will know where you stand.
meaning_hint: What situation would you like to evaluate? Be sure to say "peace" before doing so. Imagine yourself doing this out loud and think of what you would say.
reading_mnemonic: When you say "peace," you end up making a really bad pun and you hear somebody say “<reading>Heyo</reading>!” (ひょう) You look at the people around you and try to <kanji>evaluate</kanji> who said heyo, but you can’t tell. You start talking again when somebody exclaims “That’s what she said” and another person shouts “Heyo!” once again, but you still can’t evaluate who’s saying these things.
reading_hint: Imagine yourself trying to explain a situation you’re about to evaluate and your audience keeps shouting “Heyo!” every other sentence. Imagine how frustrating that would be. Get angry at your rude audience and how much they shout “Heyo.”

meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> <radical>yoga</radical> is the <radical>correct</radical> way to go through <kanji>birth</kanji>. Birth isn't easy, but people keep telling you that yoga is the right way to prepare and actually do it.
meaning_hint: Picture multiple people you know saying you should do yoga if you plan to give birth. It isn't a question of whether you want to, it's the correct way to do it. So you should.
reading_mnemonic: To prepare for giving <kanji>birth</kanji> you end up doing so much yoga outside that you get a really deep <reading>tan</reading> (たん).
reading_hint: Hopefully having a tan doesn't make birth harder, since you've worked so hard to do this the correct way with so much yoga.

vocabulary.reading: おたんじょうびおめでとう

meaning_mnemonic: You have something to <radical>say</radical>, you <radical>stand</radical> on a <radical>towel</radical>, and shout, "I <kanji>GIVE UP</kanji>!"
meaning_hint: Standing on a towel is the universal signal for giving up, but you still need to say you're abandoning whatever it is with your mouth too (just in case).
reading_mnemonic: Just before you're ready to <kanji>give up</kanji> on something, you yell, "<reading>AKIRA</reading> (あきら)!"
reading_hint: You don't know anyone named Akira, you just saw it in a movie once and it made sense, you know? So now when you've tried really hard on something, but you have to abandon it anyway, you shout AKIRA into the sky.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Dollar</radical>s and <radical>shellfish</radical> are used to pay <kanji>expense</kanji>s and <kanji>cost</kanji>s. Shellfish used to be used as currency, so they're like the coins that go with dollars.
meaning_hint: Imagine opening your bank account and looking at all of your monthly expenses. Now drag the little dollar and shellfish icons over to cover all of those costs.
reading_mnemonic: What is the biggest <kanji>expense</kanji> and <kanji>cost</kanji>? It's the <reading>hea</reading>t (ひ) bill.
reading_hint: When you see how expensive your heat is, you feel a heat going through your body too.

meaning_mnemonic: You use the <radical>power</radical> of your <radical>mouth</radical> to spit <radical>shellfish</radical> at people as a form of <kanji>congratulations</kanji>! In fact, you yell "CONGRATULATIONS!" as the shellfish come pouring out of your powerful mouth.
meaning_hint: Shellfish were once used as currency, so this totally makes sense. Just think of the shellfish as money coming out of your mouth as you say your congratulations.
reading_mnemonic: When you say <kanji>congratulations</kanji> like this, you look just like a <reading>ga</reading>rgoyle (が). You're crouching down, your mouth wide open, just like a stone gargoyle.
reading_hint: The next time you're congratulating someone, assume the gargoyle stance and dump all of their congratulatory shellfish on them from your mouth.

meaning_mnemonic: While riding on your <radical>scooter</radical>, you grow a <radical>mustache</radical> on top of the <radical>mustache</radical> you already have in order to <kanji>surpass</kanji> the people around you. You're in a scooter race and your mustache is the only thing keeping you in the lead, but someone else has a mustache too! So you grow another mustache to surpass them once again!
meaning_hint: Picture yourself running on a scooter with a bunch of other people and closing your eyes tight, willing another mustache to sprout out of your face to surpass them all.
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly, something else manages to <kanji>surpass</kanji> you all. It's a <reading>ca</reading>r (か)! A car with two mustaches is also riding on a scooter and going way faster than you.
reading_hint: Watch helplessly as the car surpasses every single one of your scooters. Both of your mustaches droop in shame.

meaning_mnemonic: Inside the <radical>building</radical> is the <radical>Winter</radical> <radical>Cow</radical>. You need to see it, so you go inside. It is deep down in there, and you'll have to <kanji>descend</kanji> to reach it.
meaning_hint: Focus on descending the stairs. There are many signs that say "To Winter Cow: descend" with an arrow pointing down. "I guess I'll have to descend," you say.
reading_mnemonic: You <kanji>descend</kanji> to the bottom and there it is, the Winter Cow. You walk up to the cow, and it swings its head back to see you. Instead of a cow's face, it's <reading>こう</reading>いち's face.
reading_hint: "Hello, thank you for descending all the way down here to see me," says the Winter Cow with こういち's face. "You thought you could use the Winter Cow to stop me, but as you can see, I got here first."

meaning_mnemonic: Taking <radical>orders</radical> from a <radical>geoduck</radical> will place you into enemy <kanji>territory</kanji>. Geoducks make terrible commanders, so if you take orders from one, expect to end up in unknown territory, potentially even enemy territory. Be prepared.
meaning_hint: Imagine this geoduck shouting orders at you to march into enemy territory. See its gross body as a mouth forms and starts shouting out orders.
reading_mnemonic: Not wanting to end up dead in enemy <kanji>territory</kanji>, you decide to escape this geoduck leader by getting on a <reading>row</reading> (りょう) boat and rowing your way outta there. The geoduck commander orders you to halt your escape, but you still get in your row boat and row away.
reading_hint: Feel yourself in the row boat as you imagine rowing away to safe territory. Hear the geoduck in the background shouting at you from shore, ordering you to return to land.
